The **Polychaeta** [/ˌpɒlɪˈkiːtə/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"),
also known as the **bristle worms** or **polychaetes** , are a
[paraphyletic](/wiki/Paraphyletic "Paraphyletic")[1] class of
[annelid](/wiki/Annelid "Annelid") worms, generally marine. Each body segment
has a pair of fleshy protrusions called [parapodia](/wiki/Parapodia
"Parapodia") that bear many bristles, called [chaetae](/wiki/Chaeta "Chaeta"),
which are made of [chitin](/wiki/Chitin "Chitin"). As such, polychaetes are
sometimes referred to as **bristle worms**. More than 10,000 species are
described in this class. Common representatives include the
[lugworm](/wiki/Lugworm "Lugworm") (_Arenicola marina_) and the
[sandworm](/wiki/Alitta_virens "Alitta virens") or [clam worm](/wiki/Clam_worm
"Clam worm") _Alitta_.

Polychaetes as a class are robust and widespread, with species that live in
the coldest ocean temperatures of the [abyssal plain](/wiki/Abyssal_plain
"Abyssal plain"), to forms which tolerate the extremely high temperatures near
[hydrothermal vents](/wiki/Hydrothermal_vent "Hydrothermal vent"). Polychaetes
occur throughout the Earth's oceans at all depths, from forms that live as
[plankton](/wiki/Plankton "Plankton") near the surface, to a 2- to 3-cm
specimen (still unclassified) observed by the robot ocean probe
[_Nereus_](/wiki/Nereus_\(underwater_vehicle\) "Nereus \(underwater
vehicle\)") at the bottom of the [Challenger Deep](/wiki/Challenger_Deep
"Challenger Deep"), the deepest known spot in the Earth's oceans.[2] Only 168
species (less than 2% of all polychaetes) are known from fresh waters.[3]

## Description[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Polychaete&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Description")]

Polychaetes are segmented worms, generally less than 10 cm (4 in) in length,
although ranging at the extremes from 1 mm (0.04 in) to 3 m (10 ft), in
_[Eunice aphroditois](/wiki/Eunice_aphroditois "Eunice aphroditois")_. They
can sometimes be brightly coloured, and may be [iridescent](/wiki/Iridescent
"Iridescent") or even [luminescent](/wiki/Luminescent "Luminescent"). Each
segment bears a pair of paddle-like and highly vascularized
[parapodia](/wiki/Parapodia "Parapodia"), which are used for movement and, in
many species, act as the worm's primary [respiratory](/wiki/Gas_exchange "Gas
exchange") surfaces. Bundles of bristles, called [setae](/wiki/Setae "Setae"),
project from the parapodia.[4]

However, polychaetes vary widely from this generalised pattern, and can
display a range of different body forms. The most generalised polychaetes are
those that crawl along the bottom, but others have adapted to many different
[ecological niches](/wiki/Ecological_niche "Ecological niche"), including
burrowing, swimming, [pelagic](/wiki/Pelagic "Pelagic") life, tube-dwelling or
boring, [commensalism](/wiki/Commensal "Commensal"), and
[parasitism](/wiki/Parasite "Parasite"), requiring various modifications to
their body structures.

The head, or [prostomium](/wiki/Prostomium "Prostomium"), is relatively well
developed, compared with other annelids. It projects forward over the mouth,
which therefore lies on the animal's underside. The head normally includes two
to four pair of eyes, although some species are blind. These are typically
fairly simple structures, capable of distinguishing only light and dark,
although some species have large eyes with lenses that may be capable of more
sophisticated vision.[4]

The head also includes a pair of [antennae](/wiki/Antenna_\(biology\) "Antenna
\(biology\)"), tentacle-like [palps](/wiki/Palp "Palp"), and a pair of pits
lined with [cilia](/wiki/Cilia "Cilia"), known as "nuchal organs". These
latter appear to be [chemoreceptors](/wiki/Chemoreceptor "Chemoreceptor"), and
help the worm to seek out food.[4]

### Internal anatomy and
physiology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Polychaete&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Internal anatomy and physiology")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Polychaeta_anatomy_en.svg/500px-
Polychaeta_anatomy_en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Polychaeta_anatomy_en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Polychaeta_anatomy_en.svg "Enlarge")

General anatomy of a polychaete

The outer surface of the body wall consists of a simple [columnar
epithelium](/wiki/Columnar_epithelium "Columnar epithelium") covered by a thin
[cuticle](/wiki/Cuticle "Cuticle"). Underneath this, in order, are a thin
layer of connective tissue, a layer of circular muscle, a layer of
longitudinal muscle, and a [peritoneum](/wiki/Peritoneum "Peritoneum")
surrounding the [body cavity](/wiki/Coelom "Coelom"). Additional oblique
muscles move the parapodia. In most species the body cavity is divided into
separate compartments by sheets of peritoneum between each segment, but in
some species it's more continuous.

The mouth of polychaetes is located on the [peristomium](/wiki/Peristomium
"Peristomium"), the segment behind the [prostomium](/wiki/Prostomium
"Prostomium"), and varies in form depending on their diets, since the group
includes predators, herbivores, filter feeders, scavengers, and parasites. In
general, however, they possess a pair of jaws and a [pharynx](/wiki/Pharynx
"Pharynx") that can be rapidly everted, allowing the worms to grab food and
pull it into their mouths. In some species, the pharynx is modified into a
lengthy [proboscis](/wiki/Proboscis "Proboscis"). The digestive tract is a
simple tube, usually with a stomach part way along.

The smallest species, and those adapted to burrowing, lack [gills](/wiki/Gill
"Gill"), breathing only through their body surfaces. Most other species have
external gills, often associated with the parapodia.

A simple but well-developed circulatory system is usually present. The two
main blood vessels furnish smaller vessels to supply the parapodia and the
gut. Blood flows forward in the dorsal vessel, above the gut, and returns down
the body in the ventral vessel, beneath the gut. The blood vessels themselves
are contractile, helping to push the blood along, so most species have no need
of a heart. In a few cases, however, muscular pumps analogous to a heart are
found in various parts of the system. Conversely, some species have little or
no circulatory system at all, transporting oxygen in the [coelomic
fluid](/wiki/Coelom#Coelomic_fluid "Coelom") that fills their body
cavities.[4]

The blood may be colourless, or have any of three different respiratory
pigments. The most common of these is [haemoglobin](/wiki/Haemoglobin
"Haemoglobin"), but some groups have [haemerythrin](/wiki/Haemerythrin
"Haemerythrin") or the green-coloured [chlorocruorin](/wiki/Chlorocruorin
"Chlorocruorin"), instead.

The nervous system consists of a single or double ventral nerve cord running
the length of the body, with [ganglia](/wiki/Ganglion "Ganglion") and a series
of small nerves in each segment. The brain is relatively large, compared with
that of other annelids, and lies in the upper part of the head. An
[endocrine](/wiki/Endocrine "Endocrine") gland is attached to the ventral
posterior surface of the brain, and appears to be involved in reproductive
activity. In addition to the sensory organs on the head, photosensitive eye
spots, [statocysts](/wiki/Statocyst "Statocyst"), and numerous additional
sensory nerve endings, most likely in involved with the sense of touch, also
occur on the body.[4]

Polychaetes have a varying number of [protonephridia](/wiki/Protonephridia
"Protonephridia") or [metanephridia](/wiki/Metanephridia "Metanephridia") for
excreting waste, which in some cases can be relatively complex in structure.
The body also contains greenish "chloragogen" tissue, similar to that found in
[oligochaetes](/wiki/Oligochaete "Oligochaete"), which appears to function in
metabolism, in a similar fashion to that of the vertebrate [liver](/wiki/Liver
"Liver").[4]

The cuticle is constructed from cross-linked fibres of
[collagen](/wiki/Collagen "Collagen") and may be 200 nm to 13 mm thick. Their
jaws are formed from [sclerotised](/wiki/Sclerite "Sclerite") collagen, and
their [setae](/wiki/Setae "Setae") from sclerotised [chitin](/wiki/Chitin
"Chitin").[5]

## Ecology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Polychaete&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Ecology")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Spirobrancheus_giganteus.jpg/220px-
Spirobrancheus_giganteus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Spirobrancheus_giganteus.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Spirobrancheus_giganteus.jpg "Enlarge")

Christmas tree worms (_[Spirobranchus giganteus](/wiki/Spirobranchus_giganteus
"Spirobranchus giganteus")_) from [East Timor](/wiki/East_Timor "East Timor").

Polychaetes are extremely variable in both form and lifestyle, and include a
few taxa that swim among the [plankton](/wiki/Plankton "Plankton") or above
the [abyssal plain](/wiki/Abyssal_plain "Abyssal plain"). Most burrow or build
tubes in the sediment, and some live as [commensals](/wiki/Commensal
"Commensal"). A few are parasitic. The mobile forms (Errantia) tend to have
well-developed sense organs and jaws, while the stationary forms (Sedentaria)
lack them, but may have specialized gills or tentacles used for respiration
and deposit or filter feeding, e.g., [fanworms](/wiki/Fanworm "Fanworm").

Underwater polychaetes have eversible mouthparts used to capture prey.[6] A
few groups have evolved to live in terrestrial environments, like
[Namanereidinae](/w/index.php?title=Namanereidinae&action=edit&redlink=1
"Namanereidinae \(page does not exist\)") with many terrestrial species, but
are restricted to humid areas. Some have even evolved cutaneous invaginations
for aerial gas exchange.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Featherduster_300.jpg/220px-
Featherduster_300.jpg)](/wiki/File:Featherduster_300.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Featherduster_300.jpg "Enlarge")

_[Sabellastarte spectabilis](/wiki/Sabellastarte_spectabilis "Sabellastarte
spectabilis")_

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Tomopteriskils.jpg/220px-
Tomopteriskils.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tomopteriskils.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tomopteriskils.jpg "Enlarge")

_[Tomopteris](/wiki/Tomopteris "Tomopteris")_ from [plankton](/wiki/Plankton
"Plankton")

Notable polychaetes

  * One notable polychaete, the [Pompeii worm](/wiki/Pompeii_worm "Pompeii worm") (_Alvinella pompejana_) is endemic to the [hydrothermal vents](/wiki/Hydrothermal_vent "Hydrothermal vent") of the Pacific Ocean. Pompeii worms are among the most heat-tolerant complex animals known.
  * A recently discovered genus, _[Osedax](/wiki/Osedax "Osedax")_ , includes a species nicknamed the "bone-eating snot flower".[7]
  * Another remarkable polychaete is _[Hesiocaeca methanicola](/wiki/Hesiocaeca_methanicola "Hesiocaeca methanicola")_ , which lives on [methane clathrate](/wiki/Methane_clathrate "Methane clathrate") deposits.
  * _[Lamellibrachia](/wiki/Lamellibrachia "Lamellibrachia") luymesi_ is a [cold seep](/wiki/Cold_seep "Cold seep") [tube worm](/wiki/Tube_worm_\(body_plan\) "Tube worm \(body plan\)") that reaches lengths of over 3 m and may be the most long-lived animal, being over 250 years old.
  * A still unclassified multilegged predatory polychaete worm was identified only by observation from the underwater vehicle [_Nereus_](/wiki/Nereus_\(underwater_vehicle\) "Nereus \(underwater vehicle\)") at the bottom of the [Challenger Deep](/wiki/Challenger_Deep "Challenger Deep"), the greatest depth in the oceans, near 10,902 m (35,768 ft) in depth. It was about an inch long visually, but the probe failed to capture it, so it could not be studied in detail.[8]
  * The Bobbit worm (_[Eunice aphroditois](/wiki/Eunice_aphroditois "Eunice aphroditois")_) is a predatory species that can achieve a length at 3 m (9.8 feet), with an average diameter of 25 mm (0.98 in).

## Reproduction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Polychaete&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Reproduction")]

Most polychaetes have separate sexes, rather than being hermaphroditic. The
most primitive species have a pair of [gonads](/wiki/Gonad "Gonad") in every
segment, but most species exhibit some degree of specialisation. The gonads
shed immature [gametes](/wiki/Gamete "Gamete") directly into the body cavity,
where they complete their development. Once mature, the gametes are shed into
the surrounding water through ducts or openings that vary between species, or
in some cases by the complete rupture of the body wall (and subsequent death
of the adult). A few species [copulate](/wiki/Animal_sexual_behavior "Animal
sexual behavior"), but most fertilize their eggs externally.

The fertilized eggs typically hatch into [trochophore](/wiki/Trochophore
"Trochophore") larvae, which float among the [plankton](/wiki/Plankton
"Plankton"), and eventually [metamorphose](/wiki/Metamorphosis
"Metamorphosis") into the adult form by adding segments. A few species have no
larval form, with the egg hatching into a form resembling the adult, and in
many that do have larvae, the trochophore never feeds, surviving off the yolk
that remains from the egg.[4]

Some polychaetes exhibit remarkable reproductive strategies. Some species in
the genus _Eunicie_ reproduce by [epitoky](/wiki/Epitoky "Epitoky"). For much
of the year, these worms look like any other burrow-dwelling polychaete, but
as the breeding season approaches, the worm undergoes a remarkable
transformation as new, specialized segments begin to grow from its rear end
until the worm can be clearly divided into two halves. The front half, the
atoke, is asexual. The new rear half, responsible for breeding, is known as
the epitoke. Each of the epitoke segments is packed with eggs and sperm and
features a single eyespot on its surface. The beginning of the last lunar
quarter is the cue for these animals to breed, and the epitokes break free
from the atokes and float to the surface. The eye spots sense when the epitoke
reaches the surface and the segments from millions of worms burst, releasing
their eggs and sperm into the water.[9]

Another strange strategy is employed by the deep sea worm _[Syllis
ramosa](/wiki/Syllis_ramosa "Syllis ramosa")_ which lives inside a sponge. The
rear end of the worm develops into a "stolon" containing the eggs or sperm,
and this stolon becomes detached from the parent worm, and rises to the sea
surface where fertilisation takes place.[10]

## Fossil record[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Polychaete&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Fossil record")]

Stem-group polychaete fossils are known from the [Sirius
Passet](/wiki/Sirius_Passet "Sirius Passet")
[Lagerstätte](/wiki/Lagerst%C3%A4tte "Lagerstätte"), a rich, sedimentary
deposit in Greenland tentatively dated to the late
[Atdabanian](/wiki/Atdabanian "Atdabanian") (early [Cambrian](/wiki/Cambrian
"Cambrian")).[11] Many of the more famous [Burgess Shale](/wiki/Burgess_Shale
"Burgess Shale") organisms, such as _[Canadia](/wiki/Canadia_\(genus\)
"Canadia \(genus\)")_ , may also have polychaete affinities.
_[Wiwaxia](/wiki/Wiwaxia "Wiwaxia")_ , long interpreted as an annelid,[12] is
now considered to represent a mollusc.[13][14] An even older fossil,
_[Cloudina](/wiki/Cloudina "Cloudina")_ , dates to the terminal
[Ediacaran](/wiki/Ediacaran "Ediacaran") period; this has been interpreted as
an early polychaete, although consensus is absent.[15][16]

Being [soft-bodied organisms](/wiki/Soft-bodied_organisms "Soft-bodied
organisms"), the fossil record of polychaetes is dominated by their fossilized
jaws, known as [scolecodonts](/wiki/Scolecodont "Scolecodont"), and the
[mineralized](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral") tubes that some of them secrete.[17]
Most important [biomineralising polychaetes](/wiki/Biomineralising_polychaetes
"Biomineralising polychaetes") are [serpulids](/wiki/Serpulidae "Serpulidae"),
[sabellids](/wiki/Sabellidae "Sabellidae"), and
[cirratulids](/wiki/Cirratulidae "Cirratulidae"). Polychaete cuticle does have
some preservation potential; it tends to survive for at least 30 days after a
polychaete's death.[5] Although biomineralisation is usually necessary to
preserve soft tissue after this time, the presence of polychaete muscle in the
nonmineralised Burgess shale shows this need not always be the case.[5] Their
preservation potential is similar to that of [jellyfish](/wiki/Jellyfish
"Jellyfish").[5]

## Taxonomy and
systematics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Polychaete&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Taxonomy and systematics")]

See also: [List of Annelid families](/wiki/List_of_Annelid_families "List of
Annelid families")

Taxonomically, polychaetes are thought to be [paraphyletic](/wiki/Paraphyletic
"Paraphyletic"),[18] meaning the group excludes some descendants of its most
recent common ancestor. Groups that may be descended from the polychaetes
include the [oligochaetes](/wiki/Oligochaetes "Oligochaetes")
([earthworms](/wiki/Earthworm "Earthworm") and [leeches](/wiki/Leech
"Leech")), [sipunculans](/wiki/Sipuncula "Sipuncula"), and
[echiurans](/wiki/Echiura "Echiura"). The Pogonophora and
[Vestimentifera](/wiki/Vestimentifera "Vestimentifera") were once considered
separate phyla, but are now classified in the polychaete family
[Siboglinidae](/wiki/Siboglinidae "Siboglinidae").

Much of the classification below matches Rouse & Fauchald, 1998, although that
paper does not apply ranks above family.

Older classifications recognize many more (sub)orders than the layout
presented here. As comparatively few polychaete [taxa](/wiki/Taxa "Taxa") have
been subject to [cladistic](/wiki/Cladistic "Cladistic") analysis, some groups
which are usually considered invalid today may eventually be reinstated.

These divisions were shown to be mostly paraphyletic in recent years.
